H0.text: The amount of water in the plant's environment is one example of a trait passed from a parent plant to its offspring.

H1.text: The amount of sunlight shining on the plant is an example of a trait passed from a parent plant to its offspring.

H2.text: The color of the flowers on the plant is one example of a trait passed from a parent plant to its offspring.

H3.text: The nutrients in the soil where the plant grows are an example of a trait passed from a parent plant to its offspring.

A4.text: Coloration in invertebrates varies based on the depth, water temperature, food source, currents, geographic location, light exposure, and sedimentation.

A5.text: The presence of genes for synthesizing carotenoids in these arthropods has been attributed to independent horizontal gene transfer (HGT) events from fungi.

A6.text: Plants, like all other known living organisms, pass on their traits using DNA.

A7.text: Polyploid individuals that are capable of self-fertilizing can give rise to a new, genetically distinct lineage, which can be the start of a new species.

A8.text: Heritability measures the fraction of phenotype variability that can be attributed to genetic variation.

A9.text: Additive variance represents, therefore, the genetic component of variance responsible for parent-offspring resemblance.

A10.text: The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy contains an entry on Heredity and Heritability.

A11.text: Progeny from the cross would then be crossed with the high-yielding parent to ensure that the progeny were most like the high-yielding parent, (backcrossing).

A12.text: Modern plant breeding may use techniques of molecular biology to select, or in the case of genetic modification, to insert, desirable traits into plants.
